discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
B - the Lambda execution role must has the permission to write to CloudWatch Logs.
A - Lambda execution role has the valid trust policy to allow Lambda to assume the role.

Selected Answer: AB
The correct answers are A and B because:

Trust policy check (A):

Allows Lambda to assume role
Required for function execution
Basic Lambda requirement
Must be properly configured


Execution role permissions (B):

Needed for CloudWatch Logs access
Required for log writing
Must include logging permissions
Essential for logging functionality



This combination ensures:

Lambda can assume role
Role has logging permissions
Function can write logs
Complete logging setup

choices.A: Check the role that is defined in the CloudFormation template and is passed to the Lambda function. Ensure that the role has a trust policy that allows the sts:AssumeRole action by the service principal lambda amazonaws.com.
choices.D: Check the resource policy that is configured in the CloudFormation template for the Lambda function. Ensure that the resource policy has the necessary permissions to write to CloudWatch Logs.
choices.B: Check the execution role that is configured in the CloudFormation template for the Lambda function. Ensure that the execution role has the necessary permissions to write to CloudWatch Logs.
choices.E: Check the role that the developers use to debug the Lambda function. Ensure that the role has a trust policy that allows the sts:AssumeRole action by the service principal lambda.amazonaws.com.
choices.C: Check the Lambda function configuration in the CloudFormation template. Ensure that the Lambda function has an AWS X-Ray tracing configuration that is set to Active mode or PassThrough mode.

questions.question_text:
A company is developing a new serverless application that uses AWS Lambda functions. The company uses AWS CloudFormation to deploy the Lambda functions.

The company’s developers are trying to debug a Lambda function that is deployed. The developers cannot debug the Lambda function because the Lambda function is not logging its output to Amazon CloudWatch Logs.

Which combination of steps should a security engineer take to resolve this issue? (Choose two.)

choices.C: Modify the value of the ProductArn attribute in the event pattern of the EventBridge rule to “anything-but”: [“arn:aws:securityhub:us-west-2::product/aws/inspector”].
choices.B: Create a Security Hub custom action that automatically sends findings from all services except Amazon Inspector to the EventBridge event bus.
choices.A: Update the Lambda function code to find pattern matches of events from Amazon Inspector and to suppress the findings.
choices.D: Create an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) topic to send messages to the application. Set a filter policy on the topic subscriptions to reject any messages that contain the product/aws/inspector string.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Filtra os eventos do Amazon Inspector diretamente na regra do EventBridge, sem a necessidade de alterar o código da função Lambda ou criar novos recursos.
Reduz o esforço operacional e garante que apenas os eventos relevantes sejam enviados para o canal de alertas.

questions.question_text:
A company uses a collaboration application. A security engineer needs to configure automated alerts from AWS Security Hub in the us-west-2 Region for the application. The security engineer wants to receive an alert in a channel in the application every time Security Hub receives a new finding.

The security engineer creates an AWS Lambda function to convert the message to the format that the application requires. The Lambda function also sends the message to the application’s API. The security engineer configures a corresponding Amazon EventBridge rule that specifies the Lambda function as the target.

After the EventBridge rule is implemented, the channel begins to constantly receive alerts from Security Hub. Many of the alerts are Amazon Inspector alerts that do not require any action. The security engineer wants to stop the Amazon Inspector alerts.

Which solution will meet this requirement with the LEAST operational effort?

choices.A: Configure S3 Block Public Access for all S3 buckets.
choices.B: Configure S3 Block Public Access for all AWS accounts.
choices.D: Deploy an SCP that includes the “aws:ResourceOrgID”: “${aws:PrincipalOrgID}" condition.
choices.C: Deploy an SCP that includes the “aws:ResourceOrgPaths”: “${aws:PrincipalOrgPaths}” condition.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D - Create SCP with the condition aws:ResourceOrgID

questions.question_text:
A company has an organization in AWS Organizations. The organization consists of multiple OUs. The company must prevent IAM principals from outside the organization from accessing the organization’s Amazon S3 buckets. The solution must not affect the existing access that the OUs have to the S3 buckets.

Which solution will meet these requirements?

choices.C: Create an S3 Lifecycle policy. Include a 5-year retention period for the S3 bucket that AWS Backup uses for the RDS snapshots.
choices.A: Use AWS Backup to apply a 5-year retention tag to the RDS snapshots.
choices.D: Create a backup plan in AWS Backup. Configure a 5-year retention period.
choices.B: Enable versioning on the S3 bucket that AWS Backup uses for the RDS snapshots. Configure a 5-year retention period.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D - The AWS backup can set the retention as required.

questions.question_text:
A company needs to implement data lifecycle management for Amazon RDS snapshots. The company will use AWS Backup to manage the snapshots.

The company must retain RDS automated snapshots for 5 years and will use Amazon S3 for long-term archival storage.

Which solution will meet these requirements?
What are the MOST secure ways to protect the AWS account root user of a recently opened AWS account? (Choose two.)

choices.A: Use the AWS account root user access keys instead of the AWS Management Console.
choices.E: Enable multi-factor authentication for the AWS account root user.
choices.B: Enable multi-factor authentication for the AWS IAM users with the AdministratorAccess managed policy attached to them.
choices.C: Use AWS KMS to encrypt all AWS account root user and AWS IAM access keys and set automatic rotation to 30 days.
choices.D: Do not create access keys for the AWS account root user; instead, create AWS IAM users.

discussion.content:
A is not correct as it is not preferable to create access keys for root user.
B is not correct as enabling MFA for other user won't help the root user in any way.
C is not right as access keys shouldn't be created for root user.

Correct Answer is DE

Selected Answer: DE
Answer D and E
DE seems to be the correct answer
